text:
For months, as Russian forces
have gathered at Ukraine’s

borders, officials here
have been preparing
for a different threat,

an attack on Ukraine’s
energy supply.

This is Inna Sovsun, a member
of Ukraine’s Parliament who has

been warning that Ukraine’s
dependence on Russia

and Belarus for power supplies
leaves the country
in a vulnerable position.

“Putin is using any sort
of leverage he can get,

and energy is a big part
of the leverage.
Ukraine is still very much

economically connected
to Russia.

We are still buying
coal from Russia.

We are still buying
some materials

for our nuclear power stations
from Russia,

and we are still reliant
upon Russian gas.

We cannot be safe until
we disconnect from Russia,

because anything
you buy from them,

they will use it against you
any time.”

On Feb. 24,
Ukraine and Moldova

will initiate an isolation test,
during which

both countries will disconnect
from all foreign energy sources,

particularly electricity lines
from Russia and Belarus.

Without them,
Ukraine will rely solely

on its own reserves of gas,
coal and nuclear power

to supply electricity
to the entire grid.

Each of its
nuclear power plants

have been running at 100 percent
capacity since Jan. 30

to make up for the
energy deficit.

The goal is to demonstrate
energy independence

for three full days without
any shutdowns.

If this test is successful,
they’ll repeat it

in the summer, and Ukraine
will formally connect its

power grid to the
European Union next year.

Viktor Kurtiev spent years
working for Ukraine’s

state-run energy company,
Ukrenergo,

and says the country needed
more time to prepare.

Integration with Europe would
be a major blow to Russia

and Belarus, both financially
and strategically,

and a meaningful step
towards confirming Ukraine

as a viable E.U. member state,
which is why it would be

in Russia’s interest
if the test failed.

One scenario is that
Russia could block Ukraine

from reconnecting
to its power supply.

There’s another scenario,
one that has played out

in previous years,
a cyberattack

on Ukraine’s
energy infrastructure.

A pair of massive attacks
in 2015 and 2017

affected banks, hospitals and
caused widespread blackouts.

And just last week, Ukraine
reported the largest

denial of service attack
in the country’s history,

and experts warn the
grid could be next.

“Power plants like this one
are constantly under

cyberattacks, and, moreover,
the adversary is actually

attacking them more often,
the power grids,

so-called transmission and
distribution companies.

Russia has this holistic
approach to hybrid warfare.

They combine conventional
military operations

with electronic warfare,
with psycho and informational

operations, and computer
network operations

or cyberattacks
as we call them.

The goal is not
just to disrupt

operation of that specific
power grid or power plant.

The goal is to create
significant material damage,

to cause panic, to convey a
message that the government
is not in control.

The people know
that Russia always

starts cyberattacks
very often together
with military operations.

You have to expect
the attack every day,

have to assume
you’re compromised,

and that’s the new
world we’re living.”
